comment.body: Ah, now I understand the logic: Thanks! The only caveat: This seems brittle: Do I get it right that --if anything changes in 'openssl/oqs-template/config.yml' _or_ in the NID assignment there (via `make generate_crypto_objects`), that the 'BoringSSL/oqs-template/config.yml' must be manually adapted (all NIDs checked!) and the script run again? No automation possible? Maybe create an issue to not forget about this?

pull_request.title: Added BoringSSL interoperability tests.
pull_request.body:
I've also added a new CircleCI job for BoringSSL interop-testing. Presently it's not a nightly-only job, but I'll change it to be nightly-only once the PR is approved.

I also haven't added a README for these tests, since I'm considering breaking them out into a separate "interoperability testing" repository once we're done with this release cycle.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+import ossl_algorithms
+import bssl_algorithms
+import helpers
+import pytest
+import sys
+import subprocess
+import time
+import os
+import psutil
+
+@pytest.fixture()
+def sig_default_server_port(server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    # Setup: start server
+    sig_alg = "oqs_sig_default"
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
comment.body: Hmm -- wouldn't usage of the `bssl s_client -root-certs` option allow us to use exactly the same "test infrastructure" (and certs) we use in openssl?

comment.body:
`make generate_crypto_objects` should only affect OpenSSL-internal NIDs. What matters for interoperability are the TLS curve IDs, which have to be manually ensured to be the same in the `generate.yml` files for OpenSSL and BoringSSL. This does not mean all curve IDs should be checked, just the ones that changed.

I don't know if it is worth automating consistency checks between the two files. I don't expect the relevant fields there (such as OIDs and code-points) to change frequently and drastically.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+import ossl_algorithms
+import bssl_algorithms
+import helpers
+import pytest
+import sys
+import subprocess
+import time
+import os
+import psutil
+
+@pytest.fixture()
+def sig_default_server_port(server_prog, server_type, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id):
+    # Setup: start server
+    sig_alg = "oqs_sig_default"
+    if server_type == "ossl":
+        helpers.gen_openssl_keys(server_prog, os.path.join('apps', 'openssl.cnf'), sig_alg, test_artifacts_dir, worker_id)
+        command = [server_prog, 's_server',
+                                '-cert', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.crt'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-key', os.path.join(test_artifacts_dir, '{}_{}_srv.key'.format(worker_id, sig_alg)),
+                                '-tls1_3',
+                                '-quiet',
+                                '-accept', '0']
+    elif server_type == "bssl":
+        command = [server_prog, 'server',
+                                '-accept', '0',
+                                '-sig-alg', sig_alg,
+                                '-loop']
comment.body:
I use `bssl_shim` instead of `bssl s_client` because the options the shim supports (such as [expect-curve-id](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl/blob/master/ssl/test/test_config.cc#L214)) makes for a more elegant way to test the TLS connection (as opposed to having to parse the output.)

That being said. I've [updated](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/pull/198/commits/ebd0a4c20b4b54f805925b61e6afb648f1822ff0) the interoperability tests: `openssl s_server` now generates a root and a server certificate, and `bssl_shim` now checks for a certificate chain of length 2 through the `expect-peer-cert-file` option.

The other way round: `openssl s_client` talking to `bssl server`, still uses just one certificate.
